  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
President Bush addressed the unpopular war and
  unrelenting violence in Iraq
  today at a Rose Garden news conference. He announced his support of the new
  war funding bill, which does not include a troop-withdrawal timetable, Jim
  Axelrod will report. We’ll also bring you a CBS News/New York Times
  poll that shows support for the war is weaker than ever: 76 percent of
  Americans think the war is going somewhat or very badly.
 
British authorities are searching for three terror
  suspects who are believed to have been planning international attacks.
  That’s raising questions about whether current screening measures, in
  place since 9/11, could stop them or anyone else determined to enter the country
  by air?  Bob Orr will have the story.
 
Plus, we’ll tell you New Jersey Governor John
  Corzine’s plan to keep others from making the same mistake he made
  – the mistake that nearly cost him his life.
 
Last night we reported on a new class of Americans
  who can’t get health care coverage due to the most minor of medical
  problems. Tonight we continue our investigative series with Chief
  Investigative Correspondent Armen Keteyian, who will take a closer look at
  what happens when people who actually have individual insurance try to
  collect on an expensive claim. The results might surprise you.
 
To wrap-up our broadcast, John Blackstone will give
  you a tour of the next frontier in communications. It’s just like good
  old-fashioned face-to-face chatting – with an edge.
 
I hope you’ll join us for this and more.
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
